message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest venous insufficiency, which is caused by increased venous valve reflux. Decreased lymphatic flow and decreased intravascular oncotic pressure are not typical causes of bilateral lower extremity swelling and pain. Decreased arteriolar resistance would cause decreased blood flow and result in cool, pale skin rather than warm, reddish-brown discoloration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the most likely cause is increased venous valve reflux. The prominent superficial veins and bilateral pitting edema suggest venous insufficiency. Decreased lymphatic flow is not a common cause of bilateral lower extremity swelling. Decreased intravascular oncotic pressure and decreased arteriolar resistance are not typical causes of bilateral lower extremity swelling and the physical examination does not suggest them as possibilities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has bilateral pitting edema and prominent superficial veins, indicating increased venous pressure. The reddish-brown discoloration of both ankles suggests chronic venous insufficiency, which can be caused by increased venous valve reflux. The other options (decreased lymphatic flow, decreased intravascular oncotic pressure, and decreased arteriolar resistance) are not likely causes for the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of both legs swelling and pain, especially worse at night, and prominent superficial veins suggest increased venous valve reflux as the underlying cause. Decreased lymphatic flow could cause lymphedema and decreased intravascular oncotic pressure could cause edema in the lower extremities, but neither fully explains the patient’s symptoms. Decreased arteriolar resistance can cause decreased blood flow to the lower extremities, resulting in cool skin and decreased pulses, which the patient does not exhibit.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including bilateral edema, prominent superficial veins, and reddish-brown discoloration of both ankles, suggest the most likely cause is increased venous valve reflux. All other options do not fully explain the patient's symptoms. The patient's hypertension and medications may contribute to the development of venous insufficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest venous insufficiency, which can be due to increased venous valve reflux. The pitting edema suggests fluid accumulation, making options B and C unlikely. Decreased lymphatic flow can also cause swelling, but prominent superficial veins are not a typical finding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has bilateral pitting edema, prominent superficial veins, and reddish-brown discoloration of both ankles, which suggests increased venous valve reflux. Decreased lymphatic flow and arteriolar resistance usually result in unilateral edema, while decreased intravascular oncotic pressure is associated with generalized edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bilateral pitting edema and prominent superficial veins suggest increased venous valve reflux as the most likely underlying cause. Decreased lymphatic flow and decreased intravascular oncotic pressure usually cause unilateral leg swelling. Decreased arteriolar resistance may cause arterial insufficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of swelling and pain in both legs, worse at night and improving in the morning, along with bilateral pitting edema and prominent superficial veins suggest increased venous valve reflux. Decreased lymphatic flow and decreased intravascular oncotic pressure would not typically cause these symptoms. Decreased arteriolar resistance would more likely cause hypertension rather than edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has bilateral pitting edema, prominent superficial veins, and reddish-brown discoloration of both ankles, which suggest increased venous pressure and valve reflux. Decreased lymphatic flow would cause lymphedema, not pitting edema. Decreased intravascular oncotic pressure would cause transudative edema, not pitting edema. Decreased arteriolar resistance would cause a decrease in blood flow, not venous stasis.
